question: 2 (e)
sols_html:
The function is decreasing between \((-\sqrt{3},\sqrt{3})\) by part (a) and so this eliminates graphs a,b,c,d,f,h,i,j,k,l.

This leaves only e and g. The slant asymptote on g is incorrect and hence this leave the correct answer e.

and so this eliminates graphs a,b,c,d,f,h,i,j,k,l.

hence this leave the correct answer e.
sols_raw:
The function is decreasing between <math> (-\sqrt{3},\sqrt{3}) </math> by part (a) and so this eliminates graphs a,b,c,d,f,h,i,j,k,l. 

This leaves only e and g. The slant asymptote on g is incorrect and hence this leave the correct answer e.
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)=\frac{2x^3}{3x^2-9}\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x)=\frac{2x^2(x^2-9)}{3(x^2-3)^2},\qquad{}f''(x)=\frac{4x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}\end{aligned}\]

Indicate which curve below best represents the graph of y=f(x).
statement_raw:
Consider the function

:<math>
f(x)=\frac{2x^3}{3x^2-9}
</math>

Its first and second derivatives are given by

:<math>
f'(x)=\frac{2x^2(x^2-9)}{3(x^2-3)^2},\qquad{}f''(x)=\frac{4x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}
</math>

Indicate which curve below best represents the graph of y=f(x).
